title: MasterChef judges: 'Dozens' of celebrity chefs turned down offers
text:
Channel 10 finally announced the new MasterChef Australia judges on Thursday.

But reaction to the news has been mixed, with some fans saying newcomers Andy Allen, Melissa Leong and Jock Zonfrillo 'aren't famous enough'.

And now The Daily Telegraph's food column Delicious Sydney is reporting that 'dozens' of candidates turned down offers from the network before the eventual three were locked in.

The new generation! Channel 10 finally announced the new MasterChef Australia judges on Thursday: Andy Allen, Melissa Leong and Jock Zonfrillo (all pictured)

The column states: 'The new MasterChef judges will be announced today but we hear Channel 10 were knocked back dozens of times before they heard a yes.'

Daily Mail Australia has contacted Channel 10 for comment.

Andy, Melissa and Jock will replace the show's original judges, Matt Preston, Gary Mehigan and George Calombaris, who quit the show earlier this year.

Before Thursday's announcement, there was speculation that Maggie Beer, Curtis Stone and Poh Ling Yeow would be the three new judges.

Unpopular job? But The Daily Telegraph's food column Delicious Sydney is reporting that 'dozens' of candidates turned down offers from the network before the eventual three were locked in. Pictured: Jock Zonfrillo

On the grapevine: Before Thursday's announcement, there was speculation that Maggie Beer (pictured), Curtis Stone and Poh Ling Yeow would be the three new judges

All three had made guest appearances on MasterChef over the years.

British chef Jamie Oliver also expressed interest in the role following the collapse of his restaurant empire.

When the judges were confirmed on Thursday, food critic Melissa said she was 'shocked' to be offered the job.

'It came as a huge surprise for me, and is, without a doubt the opportunity of a lifetime,' she said. 'I am really looking forward to getting stuck in!'

The original judges quit after the network refused to agree to a significant pay rise.

George was also facing controversy for underpaying his restaurant staff by nearly $8million between 2011 and 2017.

authors: Jess Bell For Daily Mail Australia
